Award.AwardTitle: Women in Science and Engineering Undergraduate Scholars Program (WiSE UP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of the Women in Science and Engineering Undergraduate Scholars Program (WiSE UP) is to offer competitive scholarships and academic/career-building support activities to academically talented, economically disadvantaged African American females who pursue a science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) degree. WiSE UP provides a cluster of academic enrichment and support activities designed to promote student success in completing their bachelor's degree and exploring graduate school opportunities. Intellectual merits of the project are reflected in the comprehensive nature of the program that is designed to deliver scholars with an enhanced sense of academic community, which positively impacts student learning, confidence, performance, and improved retention of scholars, who are more prepared for the next phase in their life. WiSE UP at Spelman College will make 28 awards per academic year to deserving students majoring in biology, chemistry/biochemistry, computer science, engineering, environmental science, mathematics, and physics. The project has significant broader impacts as the gender gap in degrees earned by African American women is made worse by the limited availability of funds to support student's educational pursuits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the WISE-UP program was to offer competitive scholarships and career-building support to academically talented students pursuing STEM degrees. The program sought to provide students enrichment and support activities that would promote success towards completing the B.S. degree and entering graduate school. In relationship to this, data was collected to answer the following evaluation questions:

  1. What is the relationship between the scholarship investment and successful preparation for graduate school (as defined by STEM skill enhancement) over time?
  2. Is the relationship between scholarship investment and successful preparation for graduate school strengthened over time?
  3.  Is there a relationship between scholarship investment and the actualization of financial resources for graduate school?

In the evaluation of the program, cohorts were formed to provide a mechanism for program staff to interact with participating students and distribute scholarships. It was envisioned that the interactions would provide program administrators the opportunity to also discuss academic research opportunities, organize seminars, invite students to attend conferences, and support students in coordinating summer research. Ultimately, the formation of cohorts did not result in most scholars perceiving that they were being successfully prepared for graduate school over time.

However, students majoring in the biological and physical sciences expressed fairly to very high confidence in terms of preparing for graduate school. Based on survey responses, students’ confidence was also fairly high regarding preparing personal statements, but students were not as confident in their ability to successfully interview for graduate school. WISE UP Scholars in the 2016 and 2018 cohorts were asked to indicate immediate graduate school or career plans. More students planned to pursue MD/PhD programs, medical or dental school, employment in the K12 sector, or some other career more so than those intending to pursue a PhD or MS degree in a STEM field.

An analysis of feedback based on summer research experiences, for those provided with the opportunity, reveals that summer research experiences position students well for success as research scientists and contributes, in many respects, to the emergence of their ability to think of themselves as scientist (science identity). For instance, during the 2015-2016 academic year, 15 of the 22 students interviewed indicated participating in summer research experiences. These experiences were brokered through existing Spelman programs like Global STEM (GSTEM), Course Based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CURE), RISE, and Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Students completed research experiences at Johns Hopkins, Emory University, National Institutes of Health, University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, University of Oregon, ExxonMobil, Nordstrom Corporate Technology, Arcadia University College of Global Studies (London), Frontiers in Aging and Regeneration, and abroad in London, Scotland, Spain, and France, (through GSTEM). During this time, WISE-UP Scholars worked on research projects that allowed them to do the following:

  • Map the possible interaction between the CRE element of Hepatitis C virus with host cell factors;
  • Conduct genome wide association studies;
  • Investigate the influence of a high fat maternal diet on fetal insulin sensitivity;
  • Conduct research in multisensory perception and synesthesia;
  • Work as a technical engineer in a chemical plant monitoring the production of various chemicals produced by XOM;
  • Conduct clinical trials and develop experimental designs; and
  • Conduct research on cognitive neuroscience and multisensory perception

In addition, scholars participated in internships at Meals on Wheels, Atlanta, Genentech Inc, BEE-Inspired, Apple Solar, and Walmart.

In sum, future efforts will be designed to ensure that science identity, developed through summer research experiences and increased academic year research experiences, and placement in post-undergraduate education programs, international service or employment will be used as markers of success for STEM majors. Combined, focusing on science identity development and provisions for financial support through the distribution of scholarships could result in any program at Spelman College showing, over time, the direct relationship between scholarship investment, successful preparation for graduate school or appropriate placement within graduate school or the STEM education workforce.
